Ps.: I hope things got better since then!

> [{quoted}](name=Phoenixdust,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=g1E08Kb5,comment-id=0001000000000000000000010000,timestamp=2018-10-09T14:41:08.029+0000)

> 
> So he/she was playing the game, somebody told him/her a "kys Soraka", and after this he/she just instantly went on and tried to kill him/herself? This just sounds too fckin absurd to me, and makes no sense at all. I can't imagine what would have happened if his/her account was permanently banned? :O Which is understandably a bigger stress for anyone.

What you're missing is that what leads people to suicide varies, and is never *just* one thing. It's a pile of things that build on each other. While being permabanned may be a huge stress inducer for some people (because of the effort/money put into the account), it could be a huge stress reliever for others (because they have a way to move on instead of feeling tied to their investment of effort/money). 

What is nearly universal with people suffering suicidal levels of depression is the feeling that everyone/everything would be better off if they were dead.  It may be a thought about how their life insurance money could help their family, or it could be feeling like their very existence is a burden on their loved ones. 

This is where "kys" comes in. "Kill yourself" feeds into their perception that *literally everyone* would be better off if they just died. After all, if *you* think you're completely worthless waste of resources **and** strangers think you're completely worthless and should die, then obviously you must both be right! (And of course family members just lie to you because they don't want to hurt your feelings) 

> Ps.: I hope things got better since then!

They have, thankfully! It has been a long, slow process. There was a time when they tried some medication that ended up making things worse for a time (I don't recall if this incident was in the middle of that or not). In the last year or so they've been removed from a lot of the stress inducers in their life (like living paycheck to paycheck), moved to a more peaceful place (not on a main street), got on some new medication (which really opened their eyes to "wow, thinking about suicide once or twice a week isn't normal" as they've moved past that), switching what games they play (less League, and if they do play League mostly ARAMs) and they're pretty optimistic about the future right now. They've got different stress inducers in their life (a baby, finishing a college degree, figuring out financing on a home), but it feels like they might be out of the woods now.

Still, you can imagine why both of us still take "kys" extremely seriously as a result of what happened. Not everyone is so lucky to have someone there to stop them when it gets to be too much.

> Words do things, i was talkin' about words in an ONLINE GAME'S CHAT (the order of words were badly chosen in my sentence). In real life you can harass people with simple words, it's not a question. But when you have the ability to totally annihilate the offender in a half second, just by pressing 1 button, it makes totally no sense. And people giving power to a starger's words in this situation lacks common sense and logic.

My question is where does your real life end? Are we having a fake conversation just because it's being carried out with text messages online instead of being spoken face to face? Does empathy for others have to die when you can't see or hear their reaction to what you say?

We don't have two separate lives, one online and one offline. We live and experience things in both, and they both shape us. Yes, you can remove yourself from a situation online faster than you can remove yourself from a situation in person. But when someone else, even a stranger, re-enforces an idea you've been having it's very hard to let go.

> But if you want, we can try it, add me in LoL and flame trashtalk threaten me as much as you want. I will not give a fck about what you say, if the notifications get annoying i will just block you and move on with my life. You have literally 0 power over other people on the internet, nor does anyone else have power over you.

It's not in my nature to try and put someone down like that, and I wouldn't much like the results even if I succeeded. 

Hopefully I've at least helped you see where I'm coming from, and why I disagree with people that saying things like "kys" is OK. Maybe you'll even agree with me after this. I do believe that you can be an influence to others over the internet, so I disagree with saying that you have "0 power" over others here.

> What you're missing is that what leads people to suicide varies, and is never just one thing. It's a pile of things that build on each other.

That's why it's stupid to put all responsibility on one word. (You did not do it, but some other people do.) 

> While being permabanned may be a huge stress inducer for some people (because of the effort/money put into the account), it could be a huge stress reliever for others (because they have a way to move on instead of feeling tied to their investment of effort/money). 

So permabans are okay, since for some people it feels good to get permanently banned, and only a part of them would kill themselves for it? If i say, that i like when somebody online tells me "kys" because i totally rekt him on lane, then we can put the permaban and the "kys" on the same level back again? Because i personally hate being banned, but like to get flamed by frustrated noobs. So it's one personal experience vs another one.

> After all, if you think you're completely worthless waste of resources and strangers think you're completely worthless and should die, then obviously you must both be right! 

If you are permanently banned it's shown, that you are overly toxic and you are in the 0,06% of the most hated players in the LoL community. I think saying that you are the worst trash of the community and nobody wants to play with you even online, ensures me more in my uselessness feeling, than ONE person telling me this. But of course it's always a strange thing to try to use logic in the thinking of a mentally ill person O.o

> Still, you can imagine why both of us still take "kys" extremely seriously as a result of what happened. Not everyone is so lucky to have someone there to stop them when it gets to be too much.

I understand that ONE personal experience can turn a person to think this, a lot of people believe in bearded imaginary friends in the heaven as well, after surviving a near death experience, but that does not make them right.

> My question is where does your real life end? Are we having a fake conversation just because it's being carried out with text messages online instead of being spoken face to face? Does empathy for others have to die when you can't see or hear their reaction to what you say?

On emotional level my real life ends when i talk with people who knows nothing about me. Since they do not know me, they have no base to judge me on any level, so emotionally i do not care what they say. On the logical level it never ends, since we are having a discussion, sharing ideas, forming our and each other's view all the time. But if you would tell me, that i'm ugly and useless, when you do not know anything about me, i would simply ignore your statement, and not give a fck about it. If you back up what you say with anything objective, i would think about it.

> It's not in my nature to try and put someone down like that, and I wouldn't much like the results even if I succeeded.

Kind of expected this, but you should not worry about this when i specifically asked you to do it :D

> Hopefully I've at least helped you see where I'm coming from, and why I disagree with people that saying things like "kys" is OK. Maybe you'll even agree with me after this.

Yes, i think i clearly understand your point. And "kys" being bad is not a question. I did never say either that saying "kys" to anyone is a good thing. (Yes, i said that i like to get flamed by somebody who i just rekt on lane, but it's still not a "good" thing from him to tell me to "kys", i just take it well.) I just want to say, that everyone has the right to be an asshole, until it restricts other people to do something. By being an asshole in LoL chat, you do NOT restrict any of the other players to do something what they want. (Chat can be muted, and chat has no gameplay effect, so if you want to mitigate the effect of the flamer it costs you one click.)


So maybe instead of punishing players, who voice their opinion about something/somebody or whatever. Maybe we should not encourage mentally ill people to play competitive online games, where some kind of toxicity is inevitable and then punish the players because somebody else is not mentally capable of distinguishing real life and online bantering. And yes, it sounds bad, but i will say it again: "Mentally ill people should not play online competitive games with chat possibilities, if they can not distinguish their real life from the online world." It would be the best for THEM, since things like you mentioned could not happen. Or if you know that you have mental problems at least turn off the chat...

> So permabans are okay, since for some people it feels good to get permanently banned, and only a part of them would kill themselves for it?

Breaking the rules should result in some punishment, or else the rule exists for no reason. In cases where it's impossible to judge another person's capacity to cope with the punishment (AKA: where you can't have a trial or bring more evidence forward) then the punishment should be the same for all who break the rule. 

You can argue whether permabans should exist at all, and you can suggest other punishment systems, but that would be a subject for another thread.

> If you are permanently banned it's shown, that you are overly toxic and you are in the 0,06% of the most hated players in the LoL community.

*"Because a player-triggered review found your in-game comms extremely inflamitory and offensive, your account has been permanently suspended.

You are among 0.006% of players negative enough to be permanently banned.

Other players judged your comms to be far below the standards of the League community. The vast majority of players agree that while League's an intense, competitive game, everyone deserves respect on the Rift."*

I don't see anything in there suggesting "hated", "trash", "useless", or that no one wants to play with them. Just that their comms are way below standard. 

> But of course it's always a strange thing to try to use logic in the thinking of a mentally ill person O.o

Yeah...
There is a trail of logic for them, it's just got some twists in it. 

> I understand that ONE personal experience can turn a person to think this, a lot of people believe in bearded imaginary friends in the heaven as well, after surviving a near death experience, but that does not make them right.

First, my experience represents a scenario in which 1) I was in the game with the person told "kys" 2) the person in question had suicidal levels of depression 3) things were weighting particularly hard on that person that day 4) I was in a position to stop them. It's being told to you because 5) I feel comfortable sharing it 6) I think it's important to share 7) I happen to be on the Boards often enough to see threads where people try and defend "kys" 8) I happen to think the particular poster is reasonable enough that talking about it might change their mind.

You could swap out some of those points (4 could be swapped with the person died, 7 could be replaced with talking to a reporter instead of the Boards) but in general all of them need to happen for the issue to be noticed. 

Secondly, if you doubt being told to kill yourself by strangers can contribute to suicide, then I suggest you talk to mental health specialists or professional counselors. This would be in their area of expertise, and would make them far more qualified to talk on the subject.

Third, and without getting too far off topic, belief in God isn't based on near death experiences and old books. Those most convicted base that conviction on what happens in their lives. To my knowledge there's no scientific theory on "human subconscious communicating with others without other sensory inputs", yet that's an experience that happens extremely regularly, and many (myself included) attribute it to God. Science has done many great things to expand our understanding, but it's not complete enough to dismiss God.

> I just want to say, that everyone has the right to be an asshole, until it restricts other people to do something.

And everyone hosting a party has the right to kick guests out when they're being overly disrespectful to their other guests. Riot is choosing to exercise their rights.

> Maybe we should not encourage mentally ill people to play competitive online games, where some kind of toxicity is inevitable and then punish the players because somebody else is not mentally capable of distinguishing real life and online bantering.

The problem isn't exclusive to online games, it's encompassed a lot of the internet. 

We've tried the "anything goes" approach with interactions online, and have amassed quite a body of evidence that people are more willing to act inappropriately because they're anonymous. Death threats, rape threats, encouraging suicide, and many more behaviors are just flat out unacceptable - regardless of if it's in League, on YouTube comments, Twitter, where ever. These people wouldn't walk up to random strangers at the mall and threaten to rape them and their sisters - so why are they doing it online? 

No, enough's enough. "Just don't use the internet" doesn't cut it in today's world. It's not unreasonable to expect people to display common decency, there's no need to defend those causing problems.

> Breaking the rules should result in some punishment, or else the rule exists for no reason.

I totally agree with this, but then please nobody tell me that "we care about suicidal persons" when with these punishments Rito can push a suicidal person over the edge. If they say they do not like "kys", thats okay, but do not sugarcoat it with "we care about people" because it is just unreasonable.

> Other players judged your comms to be far below the standards of the League community.

Other players judged your comms to be far below standards, so they push you out of the group, because they do not like you. You are in the 0.06% of the players who are judged this way and forced out of this community. 

Doesn't sound nice, does it? :D

> To my knowledge there's no scientific theory on "human subconscious communicating with others without other sensory inputs", yet that's an experience that happens extremely regularly.

What?! Happens extremely regularly?! That's why we have ZERO, 0, scientific report about this. Not about the mechanism, but even the effect is not published. So let me tell you straight, this does not happen regularly. And according to our current knowledge this DOES NOT HAPPEN AT ALL. Show me ONE reproducible experiment, what shows "human subconscious communicating with others without other sensory inputs"

But really, show me one!

> And everyone hosting a party has the right to kick guests out when they're being overly disrespectful to their other guests. Riot is choosing to exercise their rights.

Yes, you are right in this. I never said that Rito has no right to do this, i just questioned if this is the good way to do things :D When we accepted the ToS, we all accepted that we can be banned for whatever reason anytime :)

> No, enough's enough. "Just don't use the internet" doesn't cut it in today's world. It's not unreasonable to expect people to display common decency, there's no need to defend those causing problems.

Did i say somewhere to not use the internet? I literally said, if you do not like parts of the internet, mute it. (You do not like flamers? Mute them.) You do not like porn? Do not watch porn. Nobody forces you to watch porn, or endure a flamer's chat. You have every right to cherry pick the parts of the internet you like. But just because YOU DO NOT LIKE porn, the porn sites should not stop existing.

TLDR:
In my opinion everyone should be able to do anything (be it bad or good), until it stops other people to exercise this same right. So you should be able to flame, since it does not break the right of other people to not see your flaming. You should have right to be racist in a facebook group, and if somebody does not like that, he wont join that group. You have every right to be a christian, until you start forcing your view on other people. But you also have the same rights to be satanist and try to summon demons IF YOU WANT, and you do not force it on other people.

Anyway, this is just my idea about a good world. This is partially why i argue about punishments for chat related issues. I know that spamming "kys" is not good for somebody, but that somebody has the right to ignore it, so imho it should not be punished.

Ps.: Please send me the reproducible experiment about "human subconscious communicating with others without other sensory inputs", since what you state is true, you can be the next Nobel-prize winner.

> [{quoted}](name=Phoenixdust,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=g1E08Kb5,comment-id=00010000000000000000000100000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-10-10T14:23:34.068+0000)
>
> Ps.: Please send me the reproducible experiment about "human subconscious communicating with others without other sensory inputs", since what you state is true, you can be the next Nobel-prize winner.

First, reproducible experiment implies that you can control every factor. It's as reproducible as astronomy observations - you're at the mercy of looking in the right place at the right time as something you can't control happens. 

That said, much like astronomy, if you are willing to do the prep work and wait for it you certainly will find your results match what others have seen in similar situations.

Can't really go into more detail than that on the Boards, but I can point you to some people who can explain the prep and steps, as well as share their own experiences. [You can reach them here](https://www.mormon.org/missionaries), but to help them understand what you're looking for (I worded it *very* differently than they think about it) you'll want to tell them "I heard a little bit about the Gift of the Holy Ghost and how it can help you know the needs of others, and I want to know more about it."

If words don't influence actions, you should be a billionaire by three o'clock.

Really.

If words don't influence actions, then ALL advertisements are a complete waste of cash. If you could convince just Coca Cola that advertisements are a waste, you'd save them 4 billion a year. They'd be willing to part with quite a bit of cash to someone who could keep their revenue and market share without spending that much. (edit: good luck convincing them to pay you though. Things just happen, and words don't influence outcomes at all.)

You'd also totally reinvent the fields of sociology, psychology, and history. You'd make a fortune just off going to late night talk shows.

Words have caused every single war that has ever happened. Words have caused every single instance of marriage.
------------------------------
Making some sort of weird distinction between words on the internet and words in "real life" is something that 80 year olds would say. You exist. The people you are talking to exist. You may as well say that you can curse and berate your mother over the telephone because she can just hang up if she doesn't want to listen to it.

Looking back up at the topic of advertisements, you can click the little X to get rid of advertisements online, or go to a different page, or you can change the radio station when they have ads on, or you can change the tv channel. Those "get rid of the ad" buttons don't seem to change the overall effect of the ads.

Okay, I will not really react to the first part, since I was talkin' about words in an online game's chat. So I didn't say anything contradicting that part...

And why would you care even a little bit about what an idiot says about you on the internet. I care what people say, when they EARNED it. I wont give a flying fck about a random tard throwing shit at me online, but if my mother does it, it's a totally different scenario, since she earned my respect. 

So since you are trying to intentionally misunderstand what I say: "A random stranger's words in an online game's chat has no effect whatsoever".

If you want to prove otherwise add me and flame me, you will see how I do not give a fck about your flaming :)

If you thought that wine and flowers were not effective, you would not use them. If you thought that revving your car's engine would be effective, you would try that.

People use the tactics that they think are effective. To do otherwise is even more stupid than trying to impress someone with car noises.

First off, I'm sorry you had to deal with that behavior, and it is in no way acceptable behavior.

Unfortunately, this falls into that same hard-to-detect category as a lot of racism or homophobia but avoids the use of trigger words. On the game with the scale of League it is sadly not possible to get human eyes on every report case, nor is it possible to build an AI that will immediately and accurately detect every case of racism, sexism, homophobia, or encouragement to self harm.

As a result this behaviour, while definitely extremely problematic, often takes a lot longer to see a punishment on then would be ideal. It is, sadly, basically a limitation of the available technology in the report system.

I personally encourage you to send a ticket to player support. I don't honestly know if they're allowed to intervene with the automated punishment system in cases like this, and I know they will be unable to tell you if they take action against this particular player do to their privacy policy, but that's going to be the best way to ensure that human eyes see this specific case, and I think that's a good thing due to the weaknesses in the automated detection system when dealing with issues like this.
